element.name: Swords Tower by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

long-description.p: Swords Round Tower has a conical cap and stands about 26m high. The upper 5m of the tower appear to have been rebuilt. Here there are four very large windows facing the cardinal points. The stonework in this area is rough and crude and totally unlike the stonework lower down. The doorway is 1.66m high and less than 1m above present ground level.

In the 10th Century the Round Tower was used as a look-out post and housed the bloody remains of King Brian Boru and his son Murrough after the famous Battle of Clontarf on their way to be buried in Armagh. During the course of the decisive battle the Irish king’s army had routed the Viking invaders and at one point captured their flag. The black raven featured on the flag remains the symbol of Fingal today. Indeed the area gets its name from the Viking words ‘Fionn Gall', meaning 'land of the fair haired stranger', the term for Vikings who had settled in the area from the 8th Century onwards. After the battle many of the defeated Vikings remained on as residents in the area enriching the local Gaelic traditions with their own indigenous crafts such as wood carving and turning, wrought iron working, pottery, sculpting and garment design. The tower gives an unrivaled view of Fingal as far as the Mountains of Mourne on a clear day. John Sweetman, the United Irishman and friend of Wolfe Tone, was buried in the shadow of the two towers.

The square belfry, standing 6 meters to the southeast of the round tower was most likely built in the 14th century. The ground at a corner of this belfry is at the same level as the ground at the base of the round tower. The floor level of the belfry is said to be 1.6 meters lower than this, indicating that the ground level has been raised significantly and that the doorway of the round tower may have been closer to 2 meters above ground level when it was built.

The cross on top the tower was reputedly placed there by the Rev. Henry Scardeville, vicar from 1682 - 1704. Early drawings show it complete, much as it is today. References were made to repairs to the top in 1775, but no further details were given as to what kind of repairs took place. Floors and ladders were placed in 1832, but the ladders were unusable by 1877.
The Cache is a regular box with the usual swaps
please retrieve and replace the cache with extreme care to Prevent Muggles from Discovering the cache.

element.encoded-hints: under slab beside tree with rail

ul.li:
2010-06-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by pierrit
The last one during our holiday in Ireland. 12:00

2010-05-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by wendiglen
Found this on a lovely day in Ireland visiting due to work. What a lovely church yard with some very interesting attributes. GPS was jumping around for this one but eventually found it took the Brutus travel bug and placed in the Alfie travel bug from England, have a nice trip Alfie TFTC

2010-05-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by Boekan
Found on the last day in Irland

2010-05-07T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fitzet
This is an amazing place - I never even knew it was here. I love these old graveyards.
SL TFTC Out TB In Plastic flower

2010-04-24T15:37:41Z : Found it by Cathal75
Easy find under large slab no need to lift... Great fun..

2008-09-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
Found with JME1979 - what a lovely spot for my 200th cache!

wpt.name: GCZZG7
wpt.desc: Swords Tower by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Swords Tower
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Swords Round Tower

Swords Round Tower has a conical cap and stands about 26m high. The upper 5m of the tower appear to have been rebuilt. Here there are four very large windows facing the cardinal points. The stonework in this area is rough and crude and totally unlike the stonework lower down. The doorway is 1.66m high and less than 1m above present ground level.

In the 10th Century the Round Tower was used as a look-out post and housed the bloody remains of King Brian Boru and his son Murrough after the famous Battle of Clontarf on their way to be buried in Armagh. During the course of the decisive battle the Irish king’s army had routed the Viking invaders and at one point captured their flag. The black raven featured on the flag remains the symbol of Fingal today. Indeed the area gets its name from the Viking words ‘Fionn Gall', meaning 'land of the fair haired stranger', the term for Vikings who had settled in the area from the 8th Century onwards. After the battle many of the defeated Vikings remained on as residents in the area enriching the local Gaelic traditions with their own indigenous crafts such as wood carving and turning, wrought iron working, pottery, sculpting and garment design. The tower gives an unrivaled view of Fingal as far as the Mountains of Mourne on a clear day. John Sweetman, the United Irishman and friend of Wolfe Tone, was buried in the shadow of the two towers.

The square belfry, standing 6 meters to the southeast of the round tower was most likely built in the 14th century. The ground at a corner of this belfry is at the same level as the ground at the base of the round tower. The floor level of the belfry is said to be 1.6 meters lower than this, indicating that the ground level has been raised significantly and that the doorway of the round tower may have been closer to 2 meters above ground level when it was built.

The cross on top the tower was reputedly placed there by the Rev. Henry Scardeville, vicar from 1682 - 1704. Early drawings show it complete, much as it is today. References were made to repairs to the top in 1775, but no further details were given as to what kind of repairs took place. Floors and ladders were placed in 1832, but the ladders were unusable by 1877.

The Cache

The Cache is a regular box with the usual swaps

please retrieve and replace the cache with extreme care to Prevent Muggles from Discovering the cache.


The Windsockers
